article_title: Bankers and Romantics: The Rise and Fall of RBS
article_text:
Scotland has two global images. The first is the highlanders, swathed in kilts, living among the mountains, mists and glens—their romanticism chronicled by Walter Scott, their landscape set to music by Mendelssohn.

The second is the antithesis of romantic: a desiccated Edinburgh banker, austerely dressed, with a voice perfectly designed for expressing disapproval, never more eloquent than when telling hungry sheep about the price of grass. The Platonic idea of reliability. In the words of 19th-century British economist...

twitter.description: Iain Martin's 'Making It Happen,' reviewed for The Wall Street Journal Europe by Bruce Anderson, reminds us, once again, that there is nothing so terrifying as the sound of crashing paper.
twitter.title: The Rise and Fall of RBS

Scotland has two global images.

The second is the antithesis of romantic: a desiccated Edinburgh banker, austerely dressed, with a voice perfectly designed for expressing disapproval, never more eloquent than when telling hungry sheep about the price of grass.
